text.p: Softbank Corp has made a conservative forecast of its group profit for the year to end-March 1998 in anticipation of losses stemming from the JSkyB satellite broadcasting venture, analysts said on Friday.

Softbank on Thursday said it expected group net profit of 9.5 billion yen for the 97/98 business year, substantially lower than the market expectations that ranged from 19 billion yen to 20 billion yen.
"Softbank apparently expects a large loss from its affiliates, particularly Japan Sky Broadcasting," said Ryosuke Osagake, analyst at Nikko Research Centre.
Softbank has not made public how large a loss it expects from the JSkyB venture, the satellite broadcasting business to be launched this year jointly with Sony Corp and News Corp of Australia.
Softbank also sees 97/98 revenues from Kingston Technology, an 80 percent owned U.S. unit, of about 20 billion yen, sharply lower than the market expectation of 30 billion yen, he said.
Nomura Research Institute said it would keep its "neutral" rating on Softbank as the evaluation of Softbank's existing businesses have not changed.
